item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Curious, and Continuing, Appeal of Mark Twain in China
item.description: A biting political satire by the quintessentially American author that has long enjoyed popularity in China can provide insights into how many Chinese view democracy and capitalism.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: For decades, one of Mark Twain's satires of American politics was required reading in Chinese schools.

item.title: Currents: Finding New Meaning in Life Through PowerPoint
item.description: A 77-year-old Colombian woman discovers the joy of learning to tell stories with a computer and an Internet connection.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS
item.media:description: Lourdes del Castillo de Rumié in her home in Cartagena, Colombia.

item.title: India Ink: The Man Who Forgot He Was Prime Minister
item.description: As the demands of Indian democracy grew more vocal, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh was defined by an imperturbable silence.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:credit: Pool photo/Harish Tyagi, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressing a press conference in New Delhi on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Destroys 6 Tons of Ivory
item.description: Chinese authorities on Monday destroyed confiscated ivory ornaments and tusks in Dongguan, a city in the southern province of Guangdong, which is a major hub for the ivory trade.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: Customs officers stood guard in front of illegal ivory as it was destroyed in Dongguan.

item.title: German Leader Injured in Skiing Accident
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has canceled most of her meetings for the next three weeks after she was injured over the Christmas holidays.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sudan’s Leader Flies to South for Crisis Talks
item.description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir is meeting the leaders of South Sudan, where fighting has been raging.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: South Korea Proposes Resuming Reunions of War-Divided Families
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s overture came five days after the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, urged the creation of “a favorable climate for improved relations.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Freed Russian Oligarch Leaves Germany for Switzerland With Family
item.description: A statement from aides to Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, said he has “not yet made any plans about permanent residency in Switzerland or anywhere else.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: India Ink: A.T.M. Makers See Opportunity in Long Lines at Rural Branches of Banks
item.description: After the central bank said it wanted to include more of the country in the financial sector, cash-machine manufacturers are eager to enter a new market.
item.dc:creator: By RADHIKA OBEROI
item.media:description: A resident of Mangali village at a State Bank of India A.T.M. in Hisar district of Haryana on Nov. 25, 2013.

item.title: Sudan’s Lost Boys Are Drawn Into War at Home
item.description: The return of South Sudan’s Lost Boys for the birth of this new nation was perhaps the perfect symbol of its hope for a new beginning, which has succumbed to violence.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: Phillip Madol, one of the Lost Boys who as a youth fled Sudan’s old civil war, returned to South Sudan only to find a new war.

item.title: 14 Killed in Stampede in Northwest China
item.description: The stampede, during a religious commemoration, took place outside a mosque in the Ningxia region, an area dominated by members of the Hui ethnic group, Xinhua reported.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Ireland Stirs Homegrown Flavor Into Tech Scene
item.description: Irish officials are using grants and tax breaks to help small start-ups find room among the Silicon Valley giants that employ thousands in Dublin.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Connor Murphy, left, and Ray Smith, at the Dublin headquarters of their tech company Datahug, which also has a New York sales office.

item.title: Jiuzhaigou Journal: Fog-Wreathed Paradise, Built by a Billionaire Under a Cloud
item.description: Deng Hong, the founder of Jiuzhai Paradise, one of China’s biggest hotels, is a well-connected billionaire now under investigation by the Communist Party’s anti-corruption commission.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Staff members of the 1,010-room Jiuzhai Paradise cleaning ponds inside the resort’s lobby in September.

item.title: The Muslim Brotherhood, Back in a Fight to Survive
item.description: Members of the Brotherhood, now outlawed and underground, said they were trying to bolster their ranks for a long struggle against Egypt’s military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Muslim Brotherhood leaders vowed a long conflict in Egypt.

item.title: Iraqis Make Gains Against Militants in Key City
item.description: Iraqi security forces and their tribal allies reclaimed parts of Ramadi from Qaeda-linked militants, officials said, but the insurgents appeared to maintain control of much of Falluja.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Gunmen patrolled after clashes in Falluja on Sunday. Qaeda-linked militants appear to maintain control of much of the city.

item.title: On Tour of Mideast, Kerry Says Iran Might Play Role in Syria Peace Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry’s suggestion Sunday that Iranian diplomats might participate in peace talks on Syria was the first time a senior American official had indicated that Iran might have a role.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday that Iran might play a role at coming peace talks on Syria. Later he met with Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi foreign minister, in Riyadh.

item.title: Spain’s Solar Pullback Threatens Pocketbooks
item.description: The Spanish government has changed its mind on a law offering attractive rates for solar energy, and instead will make producers pay a charge on electricity they generate and use themselves.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justo Cruz Rodríguez faces ruin after investing in solar power in the Spanish town of Águilas.

item.title: Migrants in Israel Protest Law for Detention
item.description: Thousands of African migrants protested in Tel Aviv against a new open-ended detention law that allows migrants to be sent to a desert prison.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: At Least 15 Die in India Building Collapse
item.description: Dozens more might be trapped under rubble, but the authorities were still trying to determine how many workers were at the site when the five-story structure crumpled Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Officials were trying to establish how many construction workers were at the site in Goa State.

item.title: Eusebio, Who Represented the Best of Soccer and of Portugal, Dies at 71
item.description: Eusebio, an international sports icon, led Portugal to a third-place finish at the 1966 World Cup and was voted one of the 10 best players of all time.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGE VECSEY
item.media:description: Eusebio, left, playing for Benifica against AC Milan in a European Cup game in 1963.

item.title: The Lede: Syrians Protest Assad and Islamist Militants
item.description: Video and images posted online by Syrian activists appeared to show that anti-Islamist protesters took to the streets in the city of Aleppo and in rural areas near the Turkish border on Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Ambassador Renews Ties to His Ancestral Village
item.description: In December, Gary Locke, the departing United States ambassador to China, made his fifth visit to his ancestral village, in a region that was once the main point of departure for immigrants to America.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Power Vacuum in Middle East Lifts Militants
item.description: The bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the will or power to contain the region’s sectarian hatreds.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD, ROBERT F. WORTH and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: An explosion last Thursday rocked a Hezbollah stronghold in Beirut, one day after authorities announced the arrest of a senior Saudi-born Qaeda leader.

item.title: Senators Differ Sharply on Penalty for Snowden
item.description: Senator Rand Paul said he did not believe that Edward J. Snowden deserved the death penalty or life in prison for exposing national secrets, but Senator Charles E. Schumer said he should stand trial and face the consequences.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: U.S. Vessel to Aid Ships Stuck in Antarctica
item.description: Australia said it had asked an American icebreaker to help rescue Chinese and Russian vessels surrounded by ice floes in Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The Coast Guard vessel the Polar Star has accepted an Australian request to assist in rescue operations in Antarctica.
